intro: Sisymbrium tibeticum, commonly known as Tibetan babycorn, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Himalayas. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and cabbage. The plant is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, and it produces edible, tender shoots that are used in local cuisines. Due to its ecological significance and potential agricultural value, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists.
